item.title: Work | Future Ready Talent Program released in Macau and Hong Kong
item.description:
Wynn and insurer Aia are two of the 14 companies that are part of the “Future Ready” project, launched by LinkedIn on Thursday in Hong Kong. The program bets on vocational training in the two special administrative regions, with special focus on artificial intelligence
The LinkedIn social network, facing the world of work, launched last week in Hong Kong, a talent formation program that has the collaboration of 14 companies from the territory and Macao, namely the Aia insurer and the Wynn game operator. The program, titled “LinkedIn Future Ready”, aims to “equip professionals from Hong Kong and Macau with the skills needed to thrive in a rapidly evolving job market,” is referred to in a note of the organization. The other participating companies or entities are the Cathay Pacific airline, the Chow Tai Fook jewelry group, the PLC group, the English Schools Foundation, the FWD group, the Hop Lun, the Link Asset Management, the MTR Corporation, the company that manages the hong Kong meter, and the PCCW consultant, without forgetting Prudential, Swire Properties, which operates in the real estate market, and the Hong Kong Jockey Club. The program includes "initiatives for updating skills, knowledge exchange and [sharing] of data based information." Essentially, “Future Ready” intends to “equip companies with tools and resources needed to navigate a workforce transformation scenario and promote a culture of innovation”. Given the latest projections of the social network, which published, in January, the report "Work Change Report - Ai Is Coming to Work" [Labor Change Report - Artificial Intelligence (IA) is coming to work], the program "Future Ready" aims to make more training in this area in both territories. "The" LinkedIn Future Ready "program is a bold initiative that aims to support the work force in Hong Kong and to collect gaps in terms of competences, as well as unlocking new opportunities in growing economy," said Mei NG, director-general of LinkedIn social network in Hong Kong. The official also added that the social network will work closely with the 14 participating companies, to build “a more resilient workforce” by providing “companies that develop and implement innovative talent strategies and ensure that their employees are equipped with the skills needed to succeed in the future”. Skills below According to the same statement, before advancing to this training program, an assessment of markets was made in both territories. It is concluded that “Hong Kong and Macao perform well in cross-cutting skills and innovation-both essential to navigating the dynamic current business landscape”, and by transversal skills, “communication, teamwork and leadership” is understood. In terms of innovation, another factor analyzed, "Hong Kong exceeds the APAC average [Asia-Pacific countries] in innovation skills, reinforcing its role as a future vision business center that also promotes industry transformation." However, the neighboring region “is behind APAC average in AI proficiency”, so the “Future Ready” program consider that there is “an urgent need for initiatives to improve skills to help enable the workforce to adapt without problems to technological advancement”. There is, in this domain, a "growing demand for AI -related skills", as "77 percent of Hong Kong business leaders said they would hire a less experienced AI competencies rather than a more experienced candidate without these skills." In addition, "although transverse skills remain the strongest area of ​​Hong Kong, the region continues to be below APAC average and is late in four of the five domains of critical skills evaluated." One of the objectives of the program announced on Thursday is to “improve and requalify the labor” of both territories “for a future fueled with AI”, so that there is “a certain combination of technical and human skills”, constituting “a competitive advantage for professionals and organizations”. The 14 partner companies will have access to more than 23,000 courses available on the “LinkedIn Learning” platform that are based on 41,000 skills sets, namely “curated learning pathways, technology training, AI training and state -of -the -art learning resources”, it is explained. The future accelerates According to the same report released by LinkedIn in January, AI's growing adoption worldwide will lead to a "search for new jobs and skills." The social network data show that "more than 10 percent of hired workers currently have positions that did not exist in 2000, including functions such as data scientist, social networking manager, sustainability manager, customer success manager and AI engineer." In the concrete case of Hong Kong, by 2030, “60 percent of all skills used to do a job will have changed, with the innovations of accelerating this transformation to 80 percent”, is mentioned. Thus, it is concluded that "this rapid pace of change has created a gap of competencies that is difficult to conform in the short term." In addition to betting on professionals, the “Future Ready” program also wants to promote ideas and debates, promising, for example, “quarterly round tables for executives” and “with sector leaders to discuss the evolution of jobs, skills and learning requirements”. “The program will also provide a platform for the sharing of best practices, influencing the widest development of the workforce in all sectors,” is still added. Also noteworthy is that the LinkedIn report on changes in work structures describe the most usual forms of AI use, namely communication in human resources or marketing. Thus, "recruiters who use LinkedIn's AI -assisted messages to involve candidates are registering an acceptance rate 44 percent higher compared to the AI ​​-free messages." In addition, “marketers who use LinkedIn's ad campaign creation tool, Accelerate, are presenting a cost per 42 percent lower compared to the classic campaigns” of this social network. For this report were held several inquiries, namely more than 2,500 entrepreneurs from five countries (United States, United Kingdom, France, Germany and India). The questionnaire focused on executives from various business areas (human resources, operations or marketing) was made in nine country and had 19,991 participants from companies with over 1000 employees. This inquiry was held from 26 November and December 13 last year. In worldwide terms, in 2030 about 70 percent of each worker's tools and skills will change, with “emerging as a catalyst”, and “IMA investments [by companies] are starting to compensate: in the last two years, 51 percent of businesses that have adopted the general AI reported an increase in revenues of 10 percent or more”. “Unsurprisingly, 88 percent of top executives with top management positions said AI adoption to help accelerate business is something important to develop next year,” one reads.

item.title: Corruption | Report Alert for gaps in Hong Kong and Singapore
item.description:
The 2024 Corruption Perception Index presents Singapore as the third cleaner jurisdiction of corruption worldwide, out of 180 countries and regions. Hong Kong is in 17th place in the ranking, but the report leaves a warning: world financial centers remain vulnerable to corruption
This Tuesday was released the perception rate of corruption (CPI, in the English acronym), which analyzes corruption in the public sector of 180 countries and regions, the responsibility of the non-governmental organization international transparency. In the case of China, the CPI reveals that there was no significant change. If 100 points means a country virtually corruption, and 0 points a highly corrupt country, China registered last year 43 points in 100, rising a position compared to 2023, occupying 76th ranking position. The CPI also looks at Hong Kong's situation, which got 67 points in 100, occupying 17th position in 180 countries and regions around the world. Taiwan, is currently 25th in the ranking of 180 countries, and no change of positioning compared to the CPI of 2023. To register the presence of an Asian country on the list of the four less corrupt. This is the case of Singapore, third with 84 points in 100, following Finland (2nd) and Denmark (1st). The list of the top four ends with New Zealand. According to official CPI data, countries and regions that are considered “full democracies” have an average of 73 points, while those who have political systems in which “faults” have 47 points. According to the index, non-democratic regimes receive only on average 33 points. The CPI analyzes corruption in 180 countries based on sources such as studies or specialists, measuring corruption only in the public sector. However, it is assumed limitations in this count, as the ranking does not include "corruption of private companies, financial secrecy or transnational corruption." If the score represents "the level of perception of public sector corruption on a scale of 0-100," the country's position in the ranking is only comparison with other countries, and these lists "can change merely if the number of countries changes." Looking at the global scenario, the report points out that "once again that developed economies dominate the top of the 2024 CPI ranking," it is countries that "have long benefited a state of strong law, the functioning of government institutions and political stability-factors that contribute to a perception of low corruption levels at the inside." However, "these attributes make these countries main targets of corrupt actors for money laundering and protection of illicit gains." The Money Trail According to the report, the fact that developed economies dominate the CPI can give a false idea that these countries "are making corruption effectively and remains untouched." “This idea could not be further from the truth. In particular, the nations that constitute large financial centers are more vulnerable to the financial flows of corruption. While their strong institutions convey an idea of ​​integrity, financial sectors and regulatory staff often provide opportunities to explore gaps, reducing anti-corruption global efforts, ”is still described. In this regard, the examples of Hong Kong and other territories associated with offshore jurisdictions are presented, where it is not always possible to determine the trail of money. “Western financial centers such as Switzerland, Luxembourg, or the United Kingdom have a history of scrutiny of facilitating money laundering movements. However, non -western centers such as Hong Kong, Singapore and the United Arab Emirates progressively have played similar papers and require similar analysis. ” “Like Western homologists, they boast the existence of a strong rule of law and institutions with a proper functioning, even though bank laws, corporate structures and secret provisions allow cases of funds washing and deviation from regulations, avoiding detection” of less legal cases, is still described. It refers to the case of the transfer of African funds to financial centers, such as Carlos São Vicente, former CEO of an Angolan state company that transferred about $ 1.2 billion to companies registered in shorts, and later transferred money tanks to Singapore and Switzerland. Only for a Singapore reported account, 558 million US dollars were transferred. Opacity here With regard to Hong Kong, it is revealed that by 2023 the territory "fines on four banks in a total of US $ 3.2 million, negligent 0.0085 percent of the profits reported by these same banks this year." Still regarding Raehk, it is revealed that "there is no central registration system on the possession of beneficiaries - it is simply required for companies that maintain this information for themselves." “Some types of investment funds are still exempt from maintaining records from their owners. With over 1.4 million companies registered in 2023, maintaining compliance with monitoring these rules is a huge challenge, creating gaps that actors in the shadow can easily explore, ”he is also described. It also states that "opacity is even worse with regard to investment funds," with Hong Kong, Singapore and the United Arab Emirates "not having any form of registration of funds beneficiaries." “As a result, even the authorities have no way to know how many funds there are and how they operate in their countries, leaving the active adjacent to these funds alone. In cases where illegalities are suspected, authorities trust the beneficiaries to provide information: a process that consumes a lot of time and is not efficient, ”he adds. Money and climate In general terms, the CPI report points out that, in the Asia Pacific region, "leaders have failed to wage corruption in the middle of climbing a climate crisis." In a note signed by Ilham Mohamed, Yuambari Haihuie and UrantsetSeg Ulziikhuu, regional counselors of international transparency, they consider that “governments throughout the Asia-Pacific region continue to fail in anti-corruption promises”, drawing attention to the fact that the region faces many natural disasters and being a “home of a third of the world, with the second largest number with the second largest number of young people ”from the world. “With no concerted efforts to combat corruption now, the first generation that is facing the extreme climate change will face disastrous consequences,” is described. "Corruption obstructs environmental policies, wages climatic financing and prevents advancement in regulations and policies, making those who have less resources more vulnerable," the report, which points to the fact that corruption waging "the effective use of money" in combating climate change. Pakistan is mentioned, “which has suffered unprecedented climate vulnerabilities in recent years, with systemic governance failures and barriers in the implementation of policies - including delays in the implementation of regulations and establishment of institutions in the climate Change Act 2017 - have left the context of financing far below the US $ 348 billion projected for the end of 2030”. Also noteworthy is the case of Vietname, which had 32 projects of solar and wind energy under investigation due to “abuse of power”. The report describes "that the lack of civic space for effective inspection, as well as a limited number of mechanisms for effective complaint systems support - such as informators protection - has threatened these fundamental programs."

item.title: Defense | World expense increased by 7.4% in 2024
item.description: The world's expense with the defense sector increased by 7.4 percent in 2024, but European countries can be unlikely to keep their pace due to internal budget pressures, according to a study published yesterday. According to the Military Balance 2025, produced by the International Institute for Strategic Studies (IISS), public expense with defense reached $ 2.46 billion last year, increasing in all regions of the world, except in sub -Saharan Africa. European investment has grown in particular, especially the 23.2 percent increase in Germany, which would have surpassed the United Kingdom in military spending in second place in NATO, behind the US. IISS estimates that, as a whole, NATO European members spent $ 442 billion from the defense sector in 2024, less than a third of the total Atlantic alliance expense, which rises to $ 1.44 billion. “With the persistence of budgetary pressures in most European countries, it is likely that it is difficult to maintain the increase in expenses. The burden is not shared widespread, with some NATO countries spending more than 3 percent of Gross Domestic Product (GDP), while others remain below the base line of 2 percent, ”says Iiss in a statement. In real terms, the European defense expense has grown 50 percent in nominal terms in the last decade, according to the 2025 Military Balance, which every year makes an assessment of military capabilities and the worldwide defense economy. The study includes updated data on military structures, equipment inventories and defense budgets from more than 170 countries. IISS estimates that an increase to 3 percent of GDP from all European NATO members would grow the amount to grow more than $ 250 billion and nearly $ 750 billion if the 5 percent value was reached, as US President Donald Trump was suggested. "However, these values ​​are unattainable at this time, with some countries resorting to extra-organizational instruments to reinforce budgets," the British Study Center acknowledges. As for the US, although this country spends in defense 3.39 percent of GDP, “limitations are evident in its industrial defense base” due to the need for investment and modernization, he says. However, it states that the Russian economy remains resilient thanks to revenues from non -energetic sources, which allow you to maintain a reduced budget deficit and central bank measures. According to the military balance, it is increasingly difficult to quantify the Russian expense with the defense due to financing by regional entities, private companies and even families, which pay equipment and basic provisions. item.title: Unemployment | Association reports increased requests for help
item.description:
The Game Industry Workers' House admits that there are more people with problems in the sector, and that workers feel pressured by the higher workload, while electronic machines are seen as threat
The Game Industry Workers House announced that last year there was an increase in the number of requests for help to find a new job. The data were presented by the Association linked to the Federation of Macao Workers Associations (Faom) on Wednesday. According to the presentation by Deputy Leong Sun Iok and president of the Game Industry Workers House, last year were received 229 requests for support from people who work, or worked in the game sector. Among the requests submitted, 143, or 66.44 percent, were related to professional motives, such as the lack of employment, 15.38 percent of those linked to the candidacy for social support and 10.49 percent due to the game's addiction. At the same time, 6.29 percent of requests were related to family issues, 4.9 percent concerned the education of children and 1.4 percent were linked to other issues not identified by the Association. Regarding front line workers in the casinos, the president of the house stated that professionals currently complain about the reduction of paintings, which overloads the hours of workers maintained. Another complaint is the installation of new electronic game tables, which create negative perspectives in the face of labor reduction in casinos, as well as professional disease development and increased pressure due to the supervision of work by game companies. Leong Sun Iok cited data from the Statistics and Census Services Directorate to indicate that the game workers fell to 52,724 in the second quarter of 2024, when in the second quarter of 2019, before the pandemic, 58,777 people were employed. Successful case In November last year, the House published an inquiry into the psychological state of the game employees, in which respondents were concerned with insecurity at work, a situation that worsened in 2021. Among the assistance provided by the Association, outside the professional issues, Leong Sun Iok indicated that there was a young man who asked for help due to the difficulty in identifying his professional tastes, interests and advantages, who prevented him from deciding the professional course. This young man also showed emotional problems due to the uncertainty caused by the situation. The deputy pointed out that the case was a success, because the support provided managed to guide the young man, who opted for a job in the area of ​​information engineering.

item.title: Financial Reserve | Registered increased increase since pandemic
item.description:
Over the past year, the financial reserve has grown 35.7 billion of Patacas, in what was the best record of recent years. The reserve adds 616.2 billion of patacas, but remains away from 663.6 billion of Patacas, from February 2021
The Finance Reserve registered in 2024 the best year since the Covid-19 pandemic, after earning 35.7 billion patacas, was announced yesterday. According to data from the Macao Monetary Authority (AMCM), it was the highest annual increase since 2019, when the reserve amount increased by 70.6 billion patacas. The financial reserve earned 22.2 billion patacas in 2023, after losing this value almost four times the previous year. The value of the reserve was 616.2 billion patacas at the end of December, according to data published in the Macao Official Bulletin. Still, the value remains away from the record of 663.6 billion patacas reached in February 2021, in the middle of the pandemic. The territory's financial reserve lost 1.76 billion of patacas in December compared to November. The value of the extraordinary reserve at the end of 2024 was 431.9 billion patacas and the basic reserve, equivalent to 150 percent of the Macao Public Budget, was 153.4 billion patacas. 1.4 percent rise The territory budget for 2024 provided for a 1.4 percent increase in total expenses to 105.9 billion patacas. The Macao Financial Reserve is mostly consisting of deposits and current accounts worth 246.7 billion of patacas, credit securities of 118 billion patacas and up to 244 billion patacas in subcontracted investments. In 2023, investments yielded to the financial reserve nearly 29 billion patacas, corresponding to a 5.2 percent profitability rate. This although, by 2023, the region's authorities transferred nearly 10.4 billion from the financial reserve to the public budget. Macao's budget for 2024 provided for the return of surpluses in public accounts, anticipating a positive balance of 1.17 billion patacas, without “having to reserve financial reserve”.

item.title: Couple therapy or love in the storm
item.description: Now I work as a couple therapist, a dream that has long wanted to realize. My understanding is no longer based only on countless readings, but also on direct experience with the conflict of couples. I leave that these experiences resonate in my knowledge and my therapeutic practice, in the hope that they result in richer reflections in this space of writing. Today I want to tell you about love in the storm. A love relationship presupposes an affective bond. We can discuss the many possible forms of “couple”, but I invite you to focus on the idea of ​​two people who find themselves and seek to connect through what they are in the most intimate and deep. Usually, in this kind of relationship, there is sex - the mechanism of connection par excellence, which brings us to our most primary desires. Theory suggests that we choose our partners because they fit the long history of our affective connections, starting with the most primary relationships, such as our parents. Thus, we establish romantic bonds that, while offering the possibility of emotional reparation, also feed our dysfunctions. Love does not exist without this polarity. The bond lives in the tension between finding the love of our lives and the risk of this same love becoming in our greatest enemy. This is, of course, a caricature, but I want them to be aware of this duality. It is common for couples, when they become aware of this tension, seek therapy. Then comes an distressing question: How can the person who love to awaken me so much sadness, anger or frustration? It is the very evolution of the relationship that leads to these winding paths. Our beliefs, the way they shape our behavior and even our understanding of romantic love influence the way we deal with this ambivalence. The truth is that we have prepared little for this reality. Recently, a husband in deep anguish shared with me: “I didn't betray, nor walk behind anyone. I don't realize why we are like this. ” In couple therapy, the goal is not to eliminate the conflict, but to understand it. The mismatch is inevitable, which is why tools are sought to better deal with it. One of the pillars of this process is to create a space where one can talk frankly about the challenges of the relationship. However, this mismatch is emotionally charged and not always easy to resolve. It is not enough to offer a new map for the couple to follow a different path. It is not even the therapist's role to give simple solutions. To reconstruct a relationship, it is necessary to face a storm - uncontrolled rainwater, wind at 100 km/h and deafening thunder. The therapist helps navigate this storm so that the couple understands that love contains in itself this disruptive possibility. Deep down, the therapist confirms that even if suffering seems atrocious and the confusing mismatch, it's okay. The mismatch is part of life. The storm is a symptom of a primitive state, a reflex of the body in the face of the frustration of their emotional needs - they are proximity or removal. It is a state in which rational thinking is overshadowed by instinctive reaction. It can manifest itself as a struggle or escape, as if the partner were a predator, or as avoidance, an attempt to protect himself from a partner who seems to consume the little emotional energy that remains. Ultimately, the way we react to mismatch is linked to the way we deal with the affective bond. Regardless of the therapeutic approach used, all psychotherapeutic schools converge on this essential strategy: to make these internal mechanisms obvious. From this awareness, therapy helps the couple create new emotional "dances", promoting understanding and empathy to make the mismatch less destructive. Of course, there are couples who come to therapy at a point where the therapeutic space serves to prepare divorce or separation. In such cases, the mediation offered by the therapist allows them to maintain forms of communication based on respect. Many therapists “divorce” couples, and this is also a successful result. The stigma associated with therapy in general is a barrier. In addition to sporadic romantic dinner, or quality time together, which many therapists will surely prescribe, therapy aims to go to other sites. Investing in relationship is essential for love, either through therapy or honest conversations about the couple's dynamics. Because love does not simply happen, it survives between comfort, pleasure and conflict.

item.title: Geogostronomy and the role of Portuguese cuisine in Macau
item.description: (continuation) Kitchen chiefs are increasingly experiencing melting dishes that incorporate international flavors, remaining faithful to Portuguese roots. The emergence of new gastronomic trends, such as “farm-to-table” and sustainable cuisine, reflects the growing awareness of the origin and quality of food. Social networks have also transformed the way culinary experiences are shared and perceived. Platforms like Instagram have made it easier for bosses to show their dishes to a global audience, attracting food enthusiasts and contributing to the promotion of macanese cuisine. Through visually appealing presentations, bosses may involve customers and encourage the appreciation of intricate flavors of Luso-Macaense cuisine. Several academic analyzes of Macau's geogostronomic landscape reveal the complex interaction between culture and food. Scholars emphasize the concept of identity, illustrating how culinary practices reflect the cultural heritage and values ​​of the community. The mix of Portuguese and Chinese culinary traditions creates a distinct identity for Macao, reinforcing its position as a cultural cauldron. The investigation suggests that gastronomic experiences are vital to fostering a sense of belonging among residents and promoting community ties. The culinary events and festivals that celebrate Luso-Macaense gastronomy further reinforce the community's involvement and promote a shared cultural identity, encouraging pride in local traditions and values. The role of Portuguese cuisine in Macau is ready for continuous evolution. The growing awareness of consumers for sustainability and health will probably shape culinary trends. Kitchen heads may prioritize the use of local and organic ingredients, while exploring innovative cooking techniques that honor traditional practices. Promoting educational programs that emphasize the importance of culinary heritage can help ensure that future generations enjoy and continue the tradition of Portuguese gastronomy. By promoting connections between chefs and consumers, Macau can maintain his unique cuisine in a constantly changing global landscape. The role of Portuguese gastronomy in Macau serves as a rich example of how cultural and geographical factors intertwine to shape culinary practices. As Macau sails for contemporary influences and anticipates future developments, the essence of Portuguese cuisine continues to prosper and evolve, promising a vibrant and dynamic culinary future. The evolution of macanese culinary culture is also influenced by the change in consumer habits and globalization. The increase in gastronomic tourism in Macao led to a greater interest in traditional dishes, as visitors eager for experiencing local flavors exploit the gastronomic landscape. Restaurants can respond by raising traditional recipes to exquisite gastronomic experiences. Events such as the “International Festival of Cities of Gastronomy, Macao” also promotes the appreciation for local cuisine, drawing attention to the skills of local bosses and the importance of culinary heritage. In recent years, conscious effort has been assisted to preserve traditional methods, simultaneously integrating modern techniques and global influences. The introduction of elements such as molecular gastronomy begins to be a practice in various luxury restaurants in Macao, creating a new dialogue between traditional dishes and contemporary food science. These innovative approaches challenge the notion of authenticity, suggesting that tradition is not static but dynamic. While there are purists who advocate the preservation of original revenues, others advocate a reinterpretation that reflects contemporary food and preferences. The sustainability of Macanese cuisine in the modern context is another critical area to examine. Environmental awareness began to influence culinary practices, with an increasing emphasis on the use of local ingredients. This change improves the freshness of foods served in Macanese restaurants. Establishments are increasingly highlighting their commitment to ecological practices and can integrate in their sustainable seafood menus and organic vegetables. These practices ensure that although the kitchen remains rooted in its historical context, it continues to evolve in a sustainable way. In addition, the intersection of global trends had an impact on Macao's traditional culinary landscape. The global fascination with the melting kitchen encouraged bosses to experience unconventional combinations. This mixture of culinary traditions can be seen in the popularity of dishes such as the Macaense-Taieman lobster curry or almond cookies influenced by Portuguese and Chinese pastry techniques. These developments reflect the evolution of the taste of both local inhabitants and tourists, reflecting a broader culinary narrative that challenges traditional concepts of what constitutes macanese food. The future of Macanese cuisine seems promising, characterized by continuous exploration of identity, innovation and cultural exchange. As the culinary scene evolves, it is crucial that chiefs and gastronomy enthusiasts find a balance between respect for traditional methods and the adoption of new techniques. The potential for greater international recognition remains strong, particularly in the field of exquisite restoration, where macanese flavors can be presented with modern interpretations. However, challenges persist, namely as regards the preservation of authentic culinary practices. Discussions may arise around cultural appropriation as macanese dishes gain popularity and are adapted to various culinary contexts. The challenge lies in ensuring the maintenance of the integrity of traditional dishes and at the same time interacting effectively with a global audience. This dialogue enhances the delicate balance between adaptation and authenticity in culinary heritage. Macau's Portuguese cuisine represents a rich tapestry of flavors formed through centuries of cultural exchange, innovation and adaptation. The historical context provides a basis for understanding how these various influences intertwined, leading to a distinct culinary identity. Influential heads have defended this kitchen, ensuring its relevance in modern gastronomy, while sustainability efforts aim to keep it linked to local traditions. The interaction between tradition and modernity, authenticity and innovation will continue to shape the future of Macanese cuisine. The enthusiasm surrounding this culinary landscape promises to attract global interest, immortalizing the flavors and narratives that define this unique gastronomic heritage.

item.title: Improve the economy of Macau (i)
item.description: After Sam Hou Fai took office as the Chief Executive of Macao, he repeatedly expressed the desire to improve the region's economy, promoting moderate sector diversification and correcting the situation that leads to the game industry to master the city's economy. Macao has positioned itself as a leisure city, but its tourist model is changing 'traditional sightseeing' to 'immersive tourism' and there are many closed stores on the city streets. According to data from the Directorate of Statistics and Census Services, there were 42,996 industrial and commercial spaces closed in June 2020. In December 2024, this number rose to 43,343. These data show that the economy has not yet completely recovered after the pandemic and that the work of the Macao government at the level of economic development has become difficult. To stimulate the vitality of Macao's economy and benefit more residents of the city, several people argue that tourism should focus on the community rather than forwarding visitors to tourist attractions. Thus, the sales of stores in community areas can be increased, allowing more people to have access to tourism revenues and reducing the number of closed commercial spaces. Already part of this plan is the increase in the number of check-in points on Fulong Street and the appearance of many stalls in Coloane who sell top of gamma products. But how can we lead tourists to consume in the community? Some say that this objective can be achieved through concerts. The process would organize free transportation to take people who visit community tourist locations to the concert room. One of the reasons why Macau can successfully host these events is the fact that Hong Kong concert halls are always full. Macau can take the opportunity and provide alternative places. The concerts attract crowds so they are a great way to bring many tourists to Macau. Currently, some travel platforms, in collaboration with concert organizers, sell tickets, in packages that include stay at the hotel, meals, transportation and other items. The package is cheaper than if purchases were made individually. This model reduces the cost of travel to Macau and can increase tourists the desire to consume in the city. If the project is enriched with tourist bus services to allow visitors to access directly to tourist sites in the community areas, naturally the possibility of consuming local commerce will increase and this will be a way to stimulate Macao's economy. To achieve this goal, first it is necessary to ensure the success of the concert. Organizers have to sign a contract with the artists. But if there is more than an artist acting, you need to be very careful. The case that occurred with Messi, which was supposed to have played in Hong Kong, but ended up not playing, made the Raehk government have noticed that besides making a contract with a team, if they do not make individual contracts with all participants, the coming of some of them can be endangered. Messi's episode inspired Macau. When a concert is organized, in order to make sure that the fears that call more public will be present, it is necessary to sign separate contracts to ensure the presence of them all. Without this provisions, there is a possibility that some of these stars fail the concert. After ensuring the presence of the star, the next step is the transportation organization for viewers. Should this bus be a traditional tourist bus? Due to the current tendency of immersive travels, tourists apparently prefer normal buses to experience the city's daily life. Perhaps the society of Macao may have this innovative idea, that is, to use the macao public transport buses to perform this tourist service. These vehicles would take visitors to community tourist sites and could transport local tourists and residents. In this way, tourists would not only have the feeling of traveling in a vulgar bus, but the number of tourists who expect in transportation and congested local buses would also be reduced. And this should be taken into account because tourists carry luggage that takes up a lot of space. Tour buses would only travel between concert sites and community tourist areas. The number of passengers would be relatively low and each would have enough space, which increases comfort. The decision that these trips are paid or free must fit the carrier company. What will be the next step after guaranteeing concerts and tourist buses? Will tourists consume in community areas? We will give the answer next week. item.title: Portuguese Bookstore | Work of photographer Chris Stowers presented Sunday
item.description:
Launched in January, “Shoot, Ask… and Run!” It is the portrait of the life of a British photographer and his adventures behind the lens. Presented next Sunday at the Portuguese Bookstore, with the presence of the author, the book was born of diaries held by Chris Stowers during his trips through Asia
The adventures of a photographer in various Asian countries in the 1990s is the motto of Chris Stowers's book, released in January. “Shoot, Ask… and Run!” It is the name of the work released next Sunday at the Portuguese Bookstore from 18h. The title of the book is born of advice to the British photographer at the beginning of his travels that turned out to be of great use in everyday life. According to the book's synopsis, Chris Stowers was "plagued by stormy, both personal and international forces," fled "from the Jakarta mafia through the Borneo jungles, attacked with tear gas by Shock Police in Manila and crossed a Soviet union in implosion." But the adventures didn't end there: Stowers was even kidnapped "by a group of strongly armed Serbian militias." Thus, in the pages of this book “Stowers paints a hard, humorous and very human picture of the life of the media in Asia - and not only - during the years of expansion of the early 1990s”. The photographer has also passed Hong Kong "in the last days of the empire and analog photography." The book is therefore a parade of memories of a man who traveled a lot in search of the unknown. “Nato and nomad observer, the question is: where is your home?”, He is also questioned in the synopsis. With the seal of Earnshaw Books, this book is the second of his series of travel memories published by the publisher. From England to the world Chris left England in 1987, just left the high school with a trip to Karachi, Pakistan. He never left Asia again, having lived ten years in Hong Kong before the transfer of sovereignty in 1997, working as a photographer for Asiaweek magazine. His love for photography began soon through living with photojournalists Freelance impoverished in Peshawar, Pakistan, devastated by war, where he was at The Frontier Post. Chris Stowers joined the prestigious Panos pictures in 1992. Photographic missions and the desire to travel took Chris to over 70 countries to date, and their work appeared in all kinds of publications, including Time, Newsweek, The Economist, Forbes, BusinessWeek, National Geographic Traveller and The New York Times. The photographer also made numerous guides for “Insight Guides” and “Dorling Kindersley”, co-author of the “Insight Guide” travel book and host of various television travel documentaries.

item.title: FRC | Saturday is “Tours with History” at Centro Kun Iam
item.description:
The Rui Cunha Foundation promotes this Saturday, from 15h, another edition of the initiative “Tours with History”, which are more than guided tours of places of historical or cultural interest of Macao with accompanying some expert. This time, it is up to sculptor Cristina Leiria, author of the project of the Kun Iam Ecumenical Center, to organize the visit
Saturday is the day of another edition of the initiative “Tours with History”, organized by the Rui Cunha Foundation (FRC), which promotes guided tours, in Portuguese and English, to Macao places with historical and cultural interest. This time the tour starts at 3 pm to the Kun Iam Ecumenical Center, and is led by Portuguese architect and sculptor Cristina Leiria, author of the original project inaugurated on March 21, 1999, recently renewed and reopened on December 11, 2024. The Kun Iam Ecumenical Center was a project designed by the author, with the support of UNESCO, “aiming to perpetuate mutual respect and friendship between all peoples and civilizations,” according to the IC official page. The public art complex measures 32 meters high in total, 20 of which refer to the bronze statue of the goddess Kun Iam, which weighs 50 tons. “The base of the statue, in the form of lotus flower, consists of the contemplation room where one can rest, listen to music and read. In the decoration of the summit the artists of Macau, Kwok Woon and Joana Ling painted, on rice paper, figures, symbols and texts related to Lao Tse, Confucius, Mence and Buddha, ”says IC information. The lower floor offers a multipurpose room, with a capacity of 50 people, dedicated to concerts, conferences, movie viewing and other multicultural activities, such as art exhibitions. Active exposure Currently, there is the individual exhibition of Cristina Leiria, “moments of light with kun iam”, at the invitation of the IC to mark the conclusion of the restoration and conversion work in a multipurpose cultural tourism space, 25 years after the author's presence at its inauguration. The show, which extends until March 13, displays statues of the goddess Kun Iam and other associated works, in materials such as Jade, Crystal, Wood or Brushed Steel, and is complemented by images and videos that portray the process of design and construction of the ecumenical center, making known to the public behind the scenes of your planning and building. Born in Lisbon on April 25, 1946, Cristina Rocha Leiria lived in Mozambique between both and 17, when he returned to study architecture at the Higher School of Fine Arts, and later took a specialization course at University College in London. He deepened studies on Feng Shui, in Macao, China and Japan, and electromagnetism in France, having exercised in such different places as the United Kingdom, Mozambique, Rhodesia, South Africa, Portugal and Macao. The construction of the Kun Iam Ecumenical Center was a challenge launched by the then governor of Macao, Vasco Rocha Vieira (recently deceased), which is a space where silence has a place to exist in a specific place. The statue dedicated to the goddess Kun Iam is 20 meters high and is made of bronze, having plenty of spiritual meaning for most Orientals.

item.title: Cinema | Selected 13 documentaries and shorts in contest
item.description: The Cultural Institute (IC) has chosen 13 documentary and short film projects in the genres fiction and animation, for the third phase of the “Macau-The Power of Image 2024” program, a contest that aims to financially support young local filmmakers. Of the 13 works selected, five are documentaries, six are fiction short films and two animation. The supports awarded by the IC Rondam 1.4 million patacas that serve to cover production and technical support costs, "with a view to transforming the above 13 works in cinematic works, which will be debuted after its conclusion." For this edition of the contest, 44 candidacies were submitted, which had two evaluation rounds with a jury composed by the curator of the Singapore Film Festival Jeremy Chua, the interior director of China Huang Ji and the Hong Kong Cheruk Cherung director. The program “Macau - The Power of the Image” had the first edition in 2007, and contributed “to the formation of new cinematic talents, in order to promote local film creation and raise its quality”, points the IC.

item.title: Cinematheque | First Indian Film Festival marks early March
item.description:
Cinemateca Paixão hosts on March 1st and 2nd the first Indian film festival of Macao. The poster, promoted by the Consulate General of India in Hong Kong and Macau, features titles such as “Dangal”, with the great star of Indian cinema Aamir Khan, “Hellaro”, and “Zindagi at Milegi Dobara” and “RRR”
Bollywood movie lovers, based on romantic stories, with adventure and a lot of dance, will have two days to see some films of this industry, starring the big stars of Indian cinema. In an unprecedented initiative in the territory, the first Indian film festival takes place at the Passion Cinematheque on the weekend of March 1 and 2, with the organization of the Consulate General of India in Hong Kong and Macao and support from the Association of Indian Culture in Macao, chaired by Vitor Kumar. The festival starts with the movie “Dangal”, starring Aamir Khan, which will be screened between 10am and 1 pm March 1. The film mixes sports and action, telling the story of the former wrestling fighter Mahavir Singh Phogat, who passes the teachings of this sport to his daughters, Babita and Geeta. The young women won the 2010 Commonwealthy games, becoming two well-known fighters throughout India, winning the silver and gold medals in this mode respectively. "Dangal" debuted in 2016. Also on March 1, between 15h and 17h, "Hellaro" will be aired, a "story that tells the journey of a woman to freedom through dance", describes the organization. Dating from 2019, the film portrays the story of a woman who is trying to overcome herself, facing the most diverse challenges to get what she wants. The second day The Indian Film Festival continues on March 2, this time with the screening of “Zindagi at Milegi Dobara”, a film centered on the story of three childhood friends who make a three -week trip in Spain. The tour ends up changing the perceptions and ideas they had from life to date, gaining new ideas about friendship and love. The screening of the film runs between 10:30 and 13h. The festival is closed with “RRR - revolt, rebellion and revolution”, aired from 2:30 pm to 6:00 pm on the same day. This film was known for the best sound band award awarded in the Oscars with “Naatu Naatu”, leading India to win a prize of this category for the first time. The song eventually became viral on social networks. The 2022 film focuses on the story of a brave warrior who embarks on a dangerous mission where a policeman who serves the British army. The film is thus an epic saga passed in India from the period prior to the independence of the United Kingdom.

item.title: Hotels | 1,25 million guests received in January
item.description: Macao hotels received more than 1.25 million guests in January, a 4.7 percent drop in annual terms, was announced yesterday. In January 2024, hotel establishments in the territory had set a new record by hosting more than 1.32 million guests, the highest number of the year. The fall in January this year is “to reduce the number of guests in 5-star hotels”, according to a statement released yesterday by the Directorate of Statistics and Census Services (DSEC). At the end of the month under analysis, there were 147 hotel establishments in Macau, six more than in the same period last year, to be available 43,000 rooms (- 7 percent), says DSEC. The average occupancy rate of the hotel room guest rooms in January, settled at 89.8 percent, rising 3.9 percentage points, in annual terms, is indicated in the same note. In 2024, Macao hotel establishments welcomed more than 14.4 million guests in 2024, establishing a new historical record. The previous record, 14.1 million guests, had been fixed in 2019, before the Covid-19 pandemic, in a year that Macao ended with only 38,300 rooms in 122 hotel establishments.

item.title: Game | Galaxy's profit increased 28.3 percent last year
item.description: Last year, Galaxy's dealership profit increased 28.3 percent from the same period to about $ 8.76 billion from Hong Kong, according to a statement sent to the Hong Kong scholarship. By comparison, in 2024, the company's profit had been $ 6.83 billion from Hong Kong. With the presentation of the results, the dealership also released a $ 0.5 dividend from Hong Kong, which will be paid on June 12. At the same time, the adjusted profit before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization (EBITDA) in 2024 was approximately $ 12.19 billion of Hong Kong, an increase of 22.4 percent over the previous year. With the presentation of the results, Francis Lui Yiu Tung, president of Galaxy Entertainment, highlighted the results achieved at the premium mass segment, the one that currently produces the largest revenues in the local market. "Throughout 2024, we continued to boost all segments of the business, in particular the premium segment, which remains the main profit engine," said Francis Lui. "In a competitive market, we continue to affect resources with discipline and focus on its most efficient use," he added. Good position Compared to this year, Lui also indicated that Galaxy is “well positioned to continue to capitalize on the trend of entertainment in Macau”, and that the organization of major events “lead to a significant increase in visitors in our resorts”, which is reflected “an increase in play activity, retail sales, food and drinking revenues and hotel demand”. item.title: Tourists | Analysts say that increase does not lead to more revenues
item.description:
The Creditsights Inc. Financial Services Company indicates that many of the new visitors have a more limited purchasing power, so the spending on casinos are lower
The Creditsights Inc. Financial Services Company believes that the dissonance between the acceleration of the number of tourists and the slowness in the recovery of casinos revenues should persist this year. The idea was defended in a report by Creditsights Inc., quoted by the GGR Asia portal, signed by analysts Nicholas Chen and David Bussey. According to the explanations presented by Creditsights Inc., the slowest recovery of the game's recipes is due to the combination of two factors. On the one hand, visitors from provinces with the largest gross domestic product, such as Canton, Jiangsu, Zhejiang, Shanghai or Beijing, reached the pre-pound levels, which limits the growth margin between these players. On the other hand, the growth of visitors is due to the fact that the new tourists originated in provinces with lower purchasing power, without capacity to spend the levels of players with more money. This is a trend that analysts believe it will last this year. In January, the number of visitors increased by 27 percent, while the game's revenues recorded a six percent reduction. Specifically looking at revenues during the Lunar New Year in January, which they will have fell short of analysts' expectations, Creditsights Inc. indicated that this is explained with the fewer arrivals, in the early days of the Lunar New Year, as well as the fact that players have a lower buying power. New Trends Regarding January numbers, analysts also put the possibility of many of the new visitors looking for alternatives in the territory, which do not pass through the tables or machines of the casinos. "In January 2025, the average gross revenue of the game by visitor presented a 26 percent reduction compared to the previous year, falling to 5.006 patacas […] However, this value may be distorted due to visitors that did not go to the casinos," he was nominated. In recent months, negative factors affecting Macau's game have been multiplying. In early February, a game promoter told the GGR Asia portal that the economic situation of the interior is reflected in the VIP game in Macao and contributed to “eroding” the little left of this segment. It is recalled that with the new law of the game, the authorities changed the Junkets Law, which together with the campaigns in court against some promoters, led the VIP segment to record a major reduction.

item.title: TOURS | Number rose almost 80% in January
item.description: Last January, 239,000 excursionists visited Macao, a number that represented a marked rise of 79.2 percent over the same month last year, yesterday indicated the direction of statistics and census services. Of this total, the large majority came from the interior of China (88.4 percent), with 217,000 visitors, while they arrived in Macao last month 18,000 international tourists, plus 3 percent compared to January 2024. Among the tours from abroad, most came from South Korea (11 thousand), which grew 27.3 percent, last year. The DSEC also revealed that in January the number of residents of the MSAR that bought “trips abroad” in travel agencies increased by 18.5 percent to 38 thousand. It is noteworthy that 8,000 resident exits occurred in excursions (+12.6 percent), of which 7,000 were destined to the interior of China.

item.title: Crime | Computer crimes shoot 71.6%
item.description:
Crime in Macau rose 6 percent in 2024, in annual terms, with computer offenses to shoot 71.6 percent, the Secretary for Security Wog Sio Chak announced yesterday. Last year, violent crimes increased, with particular incidence for kidnappings, which rose almost 50 percent from 2023
The addition of the general crime last year, with the record of 14,298 cases, against 13,487 in 2023, "the continuum increase in the crimes of burla and computer crimes is due," the Secretary for Security, Wong Sio Chak, said yesterday. Over the past year, Macao police launched 14,298 criminal inquiries, 811 cases than in 2023 (+6 percent), and a slight increase, 0.8 percent, compared to 2019. Also the number of people detained and present to the Public Prosecution Service (MP) increased by more than one fifth (+21.5 percent), with a total of 5,401 individuals. Still, the volume of detained people referred to the MP decreased 18.9 percent compared to 2019. However, the highest highlight of last year's statistical data was computer crime. If in 2023 the authorities reported 578 cases of computer crime last year, the number ascended 992 - 414 more cases, ie a 71.6 percent rise. New struggles The increase in crime in the territory, said the official, was also influenced by the entry into force in October of the law to combat illicit gaming crimes, with the typification of the crime 'exploitation of illicit exchange exchange rate', "in which police reported 89 cases." This new legislation, as well as the gradual increase of tourists and the recovery of tourism and game sectors, after the Covid-19 pandemic, “led to an inevitable climb of the number of game-related crimes,” reads a government report, released yesterday. In this sense, the authorities indicated the opening of 1,456 inquiries for game -related crimes, an increase in annual terms of 349 cases, ie 31.5 percent. The authorities noted, however, that, compared to 2019, before the pandemic, the number of cases in 2024 was “remarkably inferior” -less 701, ie a drop of 32.5 percent -“which demonstrates that the work of preventing and combating specific crime” has been resulting and “exercising determining effects on potential criminals”. Also among the crimes related to the game, it is also noted in the report, the burla appears first, with 333 cases in 2024, against 257 the previous year. This is followed by usury, with 252 cases, also higher than the previous year (119 cases). Other data related to the crime, point to an increase of 7.4 percent in violent crime, with 290 cases marked in 2024, plus an increase of 21.3 percent in child delinquency, with 131 cases. In the chapter of violent crime, highlighting the crime of kidnapping that increased 48.8 percent, with a total of 61 cases, still far lower than the 353 cases recorded in 2019. With regard to the sexual abuse of children, this crime decreased last year 38.9 percent, with the registration of 22 cases. Wong Sio Chak also reported 2,001 theft cases by 2024, a slight increase of 0.9 percent in homologous terms, underlining a total of 60 cases of theft within airplanes. Drug trafficking and selling decreased 5.6 percent in the territory in the period under analysis. João Luz / Lusa

item.title: Borders | Car circulation increases about 20 percent
item.description: Data from the Directorate of Statistics and Census Services (DSEC) show that the volume of car circulation on the borders has increased, in annual terms, by 19.1 percent, and 872,900 vehicles were totaled in January this year. In the case of light cars at border stations, there were 825,916, which represents an annual increase of 20.7 percent compared to January last year. Of these vehicles, 164 thousand outputs and outputs were from Macao's single registration cars that circulated between Macao and Hengqin, while 132 thousands of starters and exits were from cars circulating under the “circulation of Macao vehicles in Guangdong province”, with increases of 38.6 and 15.2 percent, respectively. Also noteworthy is the annual increase of 10.4 percent commercial flights at Macao International Airport, with 4,961 flights. Regarding the new cars enrolled, in January there were 1,106, 358 of them electric, a break of 16.5 percent in annual terms. Such a break is due to “decreasing the number of heavy cars and motorcycles with new enrollment”.

item.title: Japan | Births fall to a new negative record
item.description: The number of births in Japan fell to a new record, increasing the challenge related to increasing social security costs in an aging society, with an increasingly reduced group of workers who pay taxes. The number of newborns in 2024 fell 5 percent over the previous year to 720,988, extending a number of nine years of decline, according to preliminary data on the population released yesterday by the Japan Ministry of Health. This reading marks the lowest value since these records started in 1899. Also the deaths increased by 1.8 percent to a record of 1.62 million in the same period, resulting in the largest annual decline as always of the total population, according to the report. The sustained decline of births in the country increases the urgency felt by a government that is already supporting the heaviest debt among developed countries. Japan's public debt will be 232.7 percent of the country's Gross Domestic Product (GDP) this year, according to the International Monetary Fund (IMF). The demographic situation in Japan is in tune with a growing global trend. South Korea's fertility rate increased last year for the first time in nine years, but with 0.75, it is still far below the rate required to maintain the population. The fall in birth in France accelerated in 2023, reaching the fastest rhythm in half a century, while China's population decreased for three consecutive years. Fewer workers means fewer tax revenues for niponic state coffers, while pressuring companies, which face staff shortages. Vain efforts Since Japan's active age population has reached their maximum in 1995, their labor market has been relatively tight. The unemployment rate is 2.4 percent, the lowest among OECD countries, and has been maintained below 3 percent for almost four years. By 2040, Japan is expected to face a labor deficit of 11 million people, according to an estimated Recruit Works Institute, quoted by Bloomberg. In 2024, a record number of 342 Japanese companies went bankrupt due to labor shortages, according to a teikoku Databank inquiry, according to the news agency. However, Japan's social security costs continue to increase as a growing proportion of the population exceeds the age of reform. For the fiscal year that begins in April, the government has attributed 37.7 billion of yen to social security, an increase of almost 20 percent over the last decade. Japan's pension system is also under pressure, with fewer contributors and more beneficiaries. Over the past two decades, the number of taxpayers has decreased by about 3 million, while the number of beneficiaries has increased by almost 40 percent, according to the Japanese Ministry of Social Security. The continuous decline in the number of births reflects, in part, the reluctance of younger generations to have children despite recent government efforts. Based on an initiative of his predecessor, Prime Minister Shigero Ishiba is promoting a package of child care policies worth 3.6 billion yen, which includes support for future parents and improvements in the working conditions of day care workers.

item.title: Xiaomi | Valuation of actions make founder in the richest man in China
item.description: The 5.8 percent rise in the quotation of Chinese Xiaomi actions on Wednesday made the technology founder and executive director, Jun Law, in China's richest man, local press reported. Law, which is also Xiaomi's largest shareholder, will thus have surpassed the Magnata Zhong Shanshan, founder of the Nongfi Spring bottled water company, and other technology sector billionaires such as Pony MA, Tencent's header - the world's largest video game and creator of Wechat - and Zhang Yiming, leader of Bytedance, owner of Tiktok. The appreciation is justified by the incursion of the company in the emerging sector of electric vehicles and the advanced supports by the Chinese authorities to buy electronic products such as mobile phones and tablets. Law said in early February that he is studying ways for Xiaomi to accelerate the production of electric cars, after the Sedan Sedan Su7, the first model of the technological company, hit the internal forecasts by exceeding 135,000 sales by the end of 2024, after launch in March last year.
